seed_pair: Voglio parlare italiano con te adesso.
I want to speak Italian with you now.
Sto cercando di imparare.
I'm trying to learn.

legos.teaches: Italian uses stare + gerund for present continuous (-ing form)
After cercare, Italian requires di before the infinitive

seed_pair: come parlare il più spesso possibile
how to speak as often as possible

legos.teaches: Italian as...as possible pattern: il più + adjective/adverb + possibile

seed_pair: come dire qualcosa in italiano
how to say something in Italian

legos.teaches: how to + verb = come + infinitive

seed_pair: Vado ad esercitarmi a parlare con qualcun altro.
I'm going to practise speaking with someone else.

legos.teaches: andare a + infinitive for going to; reflexive verb esercitarsi
qualcun altro = someone else (qualcuno + altro)

seed_pair: Sto cercando di ricordare una parola.
I'm trying to remember a word.

legos.teaches: stare + gerund for progressive; cercare di = to try to

seed_pair: Voglio provare più che posso oggi.
I want to try as hard as I can today.

legos.teaches: più che + conjugated verb for as much as one can

seed_pair: Proverò a spiegare cosa intendo.
I'm going to try to explain what I mean.

legos.teaches: cosa + conjugated verb for what clauses

seed_pair: Parlo un po' d'italiano adesso.
I speak a little Italian now.

legos.teaches: un po' di + noun with elision before vowels

seed_pair: Non sono sicuro se riesco a ricordare tutta la frase.
I'm not sure if I can remember the whole sentence.

legos.teaches: Negation with non before verb; adjective agrees with subject
riuscire a + infinitive pattern for ability
tutto/a precedes article; agrees with feminine noun

seed_pair: Mi piacerebbe poter parlare dopo che finisci.
I'd like to be able to speak after you finish.

legos.teaches: Modal potere + infinitive; potere truncates to poter before infinitive
dopo che requires conjugated verb, not infinitive

seed_pair: Non mi piacerebbe indovinare cosa succederà domani.
I wouldn't like to guess what's going to happen tomorrow.

legos.teaches: Negation with non before reflexive pronoun
Future tense with -à ending; going to = simple future in Italian

seed_pair: Parli italiano molto bene.
You speak Italian very well.
Parli italiano tutto il giorno?
Do you speak Italian all day?

legos.teaches: Italian inserts definite article (il) with time expressions

seed_pair: E voglio che tu parli italiano con me domani.
And I want you to speak Italian with me tomorrow.

legos.teaches: Italian uses subjunctive (che + subject + verb) after verbs of wanting

seed_pair: Lui vuole tornare con tutti gli altri più tardi.
He wants to come back with everyone else later on.

legos.teaches: definite article gli inserted between components
più intensifies tardi for emphasis

seed_pair: Lei vuole scoprire qual è la risposta.
She wants to find out what the answer is.

legos.teaches: embedded questions use direct question word order in Italian

seed_pair: Vogliamo incontrarci alle sei di questa sera.
We want to meet at six o clock this evening.

legos.teaches: a + le contracts to alle before feminine plural hours; o clock dropped

seed_pair: Ma non voglio smettere di parlare.
But I don't want to stop talking.

legos.teaches: negation with non before verb
di linking between verbs

seed_pair: Vuoi imparare il suo nome velocemente.
You want to learn his name quickly.

legos.teaches: possessive with article il, agrees with noun gender

seed_pair: Perché stai imparando il suo nome?
Why are you learning her name?

legos.teaches: progressive tense with stare + gerund
Italian suo does not distinguish possessor gender, only noun gender

seed_pair: Perché voglio incontrare persone che parlano italiano.
Because I want to meet people who speak Italian.

legos.teaches: relative who in clauses is che not chi

seed_pair: Presto comincerò a parlare di più.
I'm going to start talking more soon.

legos.teaches: cominciare takes a before infinitive

seed_pair: Non riuscirò a ricordare facilmente.
I'm not going to be able to remember easily.

lego.known: I'm not going to be able

legos.teaches: negation non precedes verb and be able uses riuscire
riuscire requires a before infinitive

seed_pair: Mi aiuterai prima che io debba andare?
Are you going to help me before I have to go?

legos.teaches: prima che triggers subjunctive mood (debba instead of devo)

seed_pair: Mi piace sentirmi come se fossi quasi pronto ad andare.
I like feeling as if I am nearly ready to go.

legos.teaches: Italian uses indirect object + piacere (to me it pleases)
come se triggers imperfect subjunctive (fossi instead of sono)

seed_pair: Non mi piace impiegare troppo tempo per rispondere.
I do not like taking too much time to answer.

legos.teaches: negation non precedes the indirect object + verb phrase

seed_pair: È utile cominciare a parlare appena puoi.
It's useful to start talking as soon as you can.

legos.teaches: Italian uses 'a' between cominciare and following infinitive

seed_pair: Non vedo l'ora di parlare meglio appena posso.
I'm looking forward to speaking better as soon as I can.

legos.teaches: Idiomatic - literally 'I don't see the hour of'

seed_pair: Volevo chiederti qualcosa ieri.
I wanted to ask you something yesterday.

legos.teaches: Object pronouns attach to end of infinitives

seed_pair: Volevi parlare con me stasera.
You wanted to speak with me tonight.
Volevi mostrarmi qualcosa?
Did you want to show me something?
Da quanto tempo studi italiano?
How long have you been learning Italian?

legos.teaches: Italian duration questions use da + quanto + tempo (from how much time)

seed_pair: Non vuole stare zitto quando altre persone sono qui.
He doesn't want to be quiet when other people are here.

legos.teaches: Italian negation places non directly before the conjugated verb
Italian uses stare (to stay) + adjective for temporary behavioral states

seed_pair: Non vuole leggere niente questo pomeriggio.
She doesn't want to read anything this afternoon.

legos.teaches: Italian negation with non before verb; third person singular volere

seed_pair: Non vogliamo interrompere la storia.
We don't want to interrupt the story.

legos.teaches: Italian negation with non; first person plural volere conjugation

seed_pair: Ho cominciato a pensarci attentamente il mese scorso.
I started to think about it carefully last month.

legos.teaches: linking 'a' before infinitive + clitic pronoun -ci attached for 'about it'
word order: article + noun + scorso (not 'scorso mese')

seed_pair: Sto imparando da circa una settimana.
I have been learning for about a week.

legos.teaches: progressive formed with stare + gerund (not avere + participle)

seed_pair: Ma sono un po' stanco stamattina.
But I am a little tired this morning.
Come ti senti in questo momento?
How do you feel at the moment?

legos.teaches: reflexive verb sentirsi for expressing how one feels
Italian uses in this moment instead of at the moment

seed_pair: Mi sento bene, ma sto cominciando a sentirmi stanco.
I feel okay, but I am starting to feel tired.

legos.teaches: reflexive construction for sentirsi
stare plus gerund plus a for progressive action about to happen
reflexive infinitive with adjective

seed_pair: Stavo cominciando a sentirmi meglio di ieri sera.
I was starting to feel better than last night.

legos.teaches: imperfect progressive with stare in imperfect tense
reflexive infinitive with comparative adverb
Italian uses yesterday evening for last night

seed_pair: Non stavo pensando a come rispondere.
I wasn't thinking about how to answer.

legos.teaches: Italian uses come + infinitive for how to [verb]
Negated past progressive: non + stare (imperfect) + gerund

seed_pair: O se devo migliorare.
Or if I need to improve.

legos.teaches: need to expressed with dovere + infinitive

seed_pair: Non ho bisogno di sapere tutto.
I don't need to know everything.

legos.teaches: need to as avere bisogno di (have need of) construction
Negation with non before avere bisogno di

seed_pair: Ma non mi preoccupo di fare errori.
But I don't worry about making mistakes.

legos.teaches: reflexive verb preoccuparsi with negation + preposition di

seed_pair: Perché penso che sia una buona cosa fare errori.
Because I think that it's a good thing to make mistakes.

legos.teaches: verb + che introducing subordinate clause (triggers subjunctive)
impersonal it is + noun phrase construction

seed_pair: Non mi importa di fare errori.
I don't care about making mistakes.

legos.teaches: impersonal verb importare with dative (literally: it doesn't matter to me)

seed_pair: È così, se capisci cosa intendo.
It's like this, if you know what I mean.

lego.known: if you know what I mean

legos.teaches: Italian indirect question structure with cosa + verb

seed_pair: Non sto cercando di finire il più velocemente possibile.
I'm not trying to finish as quickly as possible.

legos.teaches: negation placement before progressive construction
Italian superlative with il più + adverb

seed_pair: Mi piace fare cose interessanti con i miei amici.
I enjoy doing interesting things with my friends.

legos.teaches: reflexive construction for expressing enjoyment
adjective placement after noun in Italian
definite article required before possessive with family/friends

seed_pair: Voleva scrivere una lettera al suo amico la settimana scorsa.
He wanted to write a letter to his friend last week.

legos.teaches: a + il contracts to al
adjective scorsa follows the noun in Italian

seed_pair: Voleva mettere la sua lettera nella sua borsa.
She wanted to put his letter in her bag.

legos.teaches: possessive sua agrees with noun gender (lettera is feminine), not possessor
in + la contracts to nella

seed_pair: Volevamo darti un po' più di tempo.
We wanted to give you a little more time.

legos.teaches: object pronoun ti attaches to end of infinitive
un po' più di is the idiomatic construction for a little more

seed_pair: Non mi piace svegliarmi quando non ho dormito molto bene.
I don't enjoy waking up when I didn't sleep very well.

legos.teaches: Italian uses dative construction (it pleases me)
passato prossimo uses avere + past participle

seed_pair: Così posso ricordare come dire alcune parole.
So I can remember how to say a few words.
Non riesco a ricordare come dire quello che volevo dire.
I can't remember how to say what I wanted to say.

legos.teaches: riuscire a + infinitive expresses inability
relative what uses quello che (that which)

seed_pair: È interessante quando capisci abbastanza parole.
It's interesting when you understand enough words.

legos.teaches: Italian drops subject pronoun for impersonal expressions

seed_pair: So come fare quello che devo fare la prossima settimana.
I know how to do what I need to do next week.

legos.teaches: Italian uses come + infinitive for how to + verb
Relative clause with quello che (that which)
Italian uses definite article la and places adjective before noun for time expressions

seed_pair: Non so ancora come dire abbastanza parole diverse.
I don't know how to say enough different words yet.

legos.teaches: Negation with non before verb, subject pronoun dropped
Italian uses come + infinitive for how to + verb
Adjective follows noun in Italian

seed_pair: Potrebbe ripetere un po' più lentamente?
Could you say that again a little more slowly?

legos.teaches: Italian intensifier stacking: un po' + più + adverb

seed_pair: Non sono sicuro se posso aiutarti allo stesso tempo.
I'm not sure if I can help you at the same time.

legos.teaches: negation placement: non precedes verb
contraction a+lo=allo before masculine noun

seed_pair: Sei sicuro che non ti dispiace aiutarmi?
Are you sure you don't mind helping me?

legos.teaches: dispiacere uses indirect object pronoun (ti dispiace = it displeases you)

seed_pair: Imparare l'italiano non è facile ma è divertente.
Learning Italian is not easy but it is fun.

legos.teaches: Negation with 'non è' before adjective
Impersonal 'è' + adjective construction

seed_pair: È importante prendersi il tempo per mettersi alla prova.
It is important to take time to test yourself.

legos.teaches: Impersonal 'è' + adjective for general statements
Reflexive verb 'prendersi' with definite article
Idiomatic reflexive expression for self-testing

seed_pair: Non è difficile trovare la risposta.
It is not difficult to find the answer.

legos.teaches: Feminine article 'la' with feminine noun
Negation pattern 'non è' + adjective for impersonal statements

seed_pair: Perché vuoi fermarti?
Why do you want to stop?
Cosa cerchi?
What are you looking for?
Non voleva badare al cane giovane tutto il pomeriggio.
He didn't want to look after the young dog all afternoon.

legos.teaches: negation non precedes verb; subject pronoun omitted (implied in verb conjugation)
adjectives typically follow nouns in Italian
time expressions use definite article in Italian

seed_pair: Non voleva dirmi dov'era.
She didn't want to tell me where it was.

legos.teaches: dove + era contracts to dov'era

seed_pair: Non volevamo far sentire la verità a nessuno.
We didn't want to let anyone hear the truth.

legos.teaches: causative construction with far + infinitive

seed_pair: Penso che tu stia andando molto bene.
I think that you're doing very well.

legos.teaches: penso che triggers subjunctive mood
subjunctive progressive with stare + gerund

seed_pair: Grazie mille, ma ho ancora da imparare.
Thank you very much, but I've got more to learn.

legos.teaches: Italian uses mille (thousand) for emphasis instead of molto
avere + da + infinitive for obligation; ancora placement before da

seed_pair: Grazie mille per aiutarmi a capire.
Thank you very much for helping me to understand.

legos.teaches: Italian uses mille (thousand) for emphasis
per + infinitive with attached pronoun (-mi); a + infinitive for purpose clauses

seed_pair: Hai ancora da imparare?
Have you got more to learn?

legos.teaches: da + infinitive for things remaining to be done; ancora for more/still

upchunked_mtypes.teaches: When 'imparare' takes a language as direct object (as gerund subject of sentence), Italian requires the definite article: l'italiano
After cercare, Italian requires 'di' before the infinitive: cercare di + infinitive
After riuscire (to manage/succeed), Italian requires 'a' before the infinitive: riuscire a + infinitive
Riuscire expresses 'managing to' or 'succeeding at' something, requiring 'a' before infinitive. Posso is general ability.
When 'we' is the subject and 'meeting each other' is implied, the reflexive pronoun '-ci' attaches to the infinitive: incontrarci
The expression 'prendersi il tempo' (to take time) requires the definite article 'il' before 'tempo'
'Quello che' is used for relative clauses meaning 'that which' or 'the thing that'. 'Cosa' is used in direct questions and simple constructions.
